You have the basic premise but you are off in one regard.

If the sun were replaced by a black hole we would not orbit the black hole, but would be relatively quickly pulled in due to the enormous change in gravitational magnitude. Our mass would not be sufficient enough to slow down the process of encroachment.

We're not near the event horizon. The event horizon is known as the "point of no return" because objects moving at the speed of light cannot get out. Also, light entering the black hole is warped. We can tell, based on the light we see from other galaxies, that we are not within the event horizon of the black hole at the center of our galaxy. There are a lot of other ways we can tell, but this is the most basic.

Your explanation doesn't sound right.
Earth ranges from 147 to 152 million km distant from Sun - a difference of 5 million km (~3 million miles) between perihelion and aphelion.
The diameter of the Earth is about 12,700 km (8,000 miles).

The axial tilt does not change the distance to the Sun in any significant way at all. In both cases, it is the angle of facing (luminous flux) that matters, not the distance.

Please revise your hypotheses.

Perihelion (near the Sun) is about 91-92 million miles, and aphelion (furthest from Sun) is about 93-94 million miles - not enough difference to notice.
It's how much of your hemisphere is pointed toward the Sun that determines seasonal heat/cold (viz. axial tilt.)

The elliptical orbit isn't nearly as pronounced as they picture in the diagram. In the northern hemisphere, where most of the land and people are, it's winter when we're closest to the sun and summer when we're the farthest away, and so the seasons tend to be a (tiny) bit more temperate on the northern half of the globe.
Also, it's less the distance to the sun that matters, and much more the amount of sunlight you recieve in a day, that dictates seasons/temperature.

simply because when compared to perfectly circular orbit, the "error margin" our elliptical orbit takes us on is less than the radius of the Earth, it's not wildly elliptical like the exaggerated diagram shown in the video.  Just not exactly perfectly circular.  therefore the tilt is enough to bring us closer to the sun while the elliptical shape itself is not.

Seasons are not due to the distance from the sun: they're due to the angle at which the sun's light hit's different parts of the earth, and thus the intensity of that light. Hence why having an orbit which brings us slightly closer or farther from the sun does nothing similar :)
This is also one of the causes of natural global warming, as in us moving closer to the sun causes tempretures to rise by a few degrees sometimes more.

Because the tilt determines how much direct sunlight hits the surface. Light that radiates to us at a more direct angle will be felt as hotter while light that skims across the surface is diffused more and comes off feeling cooler. 

That's why the sun reaches higher spots in the visible sky in the summer and why the sun stays closer to the horizon during the winter.
How come it doesn't get extremely hot when our elliptical orbit is in the stage closest to the sun?

The axial tilt affects the seasons by determining how directly the sun's energy hits a particular hemisphere.

The orbit depicted in the video is definitely not to scale; our orbit is actually very close to being circular, so the effects aren't as drastic. The difference between our closest and farthest distances from the sun is only ~.03 AU (roughly 3 million miles or 5 million km)

You mean slightly elliptical. The earth does not have a elliptical orbit because elliptical is means we have the orbit of a oval and slightly elliptical means we have somewhat of an orbit of a perfect circle.

The elliptical orbit is not that extreme, the closest the Earth gets being 147 million KM (I think) and the farthest being 152 million KM which is only a 3-4% difference.

The tilt (being approximately 23 or 24 degrees) ensures that, when Earth is on one side of it's orbit a certain hemisphere gets more direct angle sunlight for a longer period of time (hence why the days are longer in the summer) 
and when it's on the other side of it's orbit the angle is less direct and the days are shorter.

Because tilt affects how much atmosphere the sun's light has to travel through to reach us. If you think about it, the distance we are from the sun during summer and winter are relatively equal to each other. Also, different hemispheres experience those seasons simultaneously. So the ellipse would hardly be affecting the seasons in that manner.

Because the habitable zone for our solar system stretches between Venus at 0.72 AU (108,000,000 km; 67,000,000 mi) all the way to Mars at 1.52 AU (227,900,000 km; 141,600,000 mi). The earths orbit at perihelion (closest distance to the sun) is approximately 147,100,000 kilometers (91,400,000 mi) while it's aphelion (farthest distance from the sun) is approximately 152,100,000 kilometers (94,500,000 mi). This is the reason our orbit can be elliptical.

Because the Earth's orbit isn't very eccentric. Its distance from the Sun only varies about 3% over the course of a year. But from winter to summer, the axis goes from being pointed 23.5 degrees away to 23.5 degrees towards. That's a total of 47 degrees, which is quite a large change.

Around a theoretical black hole is a region known as the event horizon. This is the point at which the escape velocity is equal to the speed of light. It is also the point at which TIME STANDS STILL! So not only can nothing escape from a black hole, nothing can enter either. Why because you would be waiting for ever for anything to cross the event horizon.
